elements.content: A series of mercury dithioether coordination polymers were synthesized from mercury dihalides and rigid xylyl dithioethers containing methyl, t-butyl, and benzyl pendant groups (ligands 3a–c). The resulting coordination polymers were examined by X-ray crystallography. Changes in sterics surrounding mercury result in structures ranging from one-dimensional polymers (e.g., (3a·HgI2)∞, (3b·Hg2Cl4)∞, (3b·HgBr2)∞) to two-dimensional sheets (e.g., (3c·HgCl2)∞) and three-dimensional extended networks (e.g., [(3c)2(HgBr2)3]∞) from crystallizations which were conducted under identical conditions with the same 1:1 stoichiometry. Bridging mercury–halide bonds were found to play a surprisingly large role in governing the final structures.

Changes in sterics surrounding mercury result in structures ranging from one-dimensional polymers (e.g., (3a⋅HgI2)∞, (3b⋅Hg2Cl4)∞, (3b⋅HgBr2)∞) to two-dimensional sheets (e.g., (3c⋅HgCl2)∞) and three-dimensional extended networks (e.g., [(3c)2(HgBr2)3]∞) from crystallizations which were conducted under identical conditions with the same 1:1 stoichiometry. Bridging mercury-halide bonds were found to play a surprisingly large role in governing the final structures.

elements.content: Coordination polymers of dixylyldithioethers and mercury halides were crystallized. Changes in sterics surrounding mercury result in structures ranging from one-dimensional polymers (e.g., (3a·HgI2)∞, (3b·Hg2Cl4)∞, (3b·HgBr2)∞) to two-dimensional sheets (e.g., (3c·HgCl2)∞) and three-dimensional extended networks (e.g., (3c)2(HgBr2)3]∞) from crystallizations which were conducted under identical conditions with the same 1:1 stoichiometry.

elements.content: Strong evidence exists for the chalcogenicity of mercury, ranging from the deleterious effects of thiolate coordination by cysteine residues in proteins and enzymes to the reduction of bioavailable selenium as a result of its interaction with mercury. As a result of the high affinity between sulfur and mercury, the coordination chemistry of sulfur-containing ligands and Hg­(II) has been widely studied in the areas of medicine, waste remediation, and sensor design. This affinity has been exploited to form many coordination polymers with organic dithioethers, and a variety of coordination polymer types have been observed. We have completed a systematic study of these structures looking particularly at the effect of the sterics of the ligand and the counterion present on mercury using p-xylylene-centered dithioethers as our ligand scaffold. The rigidity of this central spacer should ensure polymer formation over mononuclear metal ion chelation. The facile synthesis of these thioether ligands has enabled this broader survey of ligand types by substituting different groups at sulfur. By changing the size of the ligand end group and the halogen counterion in the polymer, we observe structures ranging from one-dimensional (1D) polymers without any interchain close contacts to three-dimensional (3D) networks containing halide-bridged metal–ligand oligomers. The variety of structure types observed provides insight into trends in mercury coordination and may be useful in designing new mercury passivation strategies and developing design strategies for supramolecular Hg-coordination chemistry. The persistence of mercury–halide bridging has been well studied, and in future work we seek to develop supramolecular design strategies to target these specific structural motifs.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Strong evidence exists for the chalcogenicity of mercury, ranging from the deleterious effects of thiolate coordination by cysteine residues in proteins and enzymes to the reduction of bioavailable selenium as a result of its interaction with mercury. As a result of the high affinity between sulfur and mercury, the coordination chemistry of sulfur-containing ligands and Hg(II) has been widely studied in the areas of medicine, waste remediation, and sensor design. This affinity has been exploited to form many coordination polymers with organic dithioethers, and a variety of coordination polymer types have been observed. We have completed a systematic study of these structures looking particularly at the effect of the sterics of the ligand and the counterion present on mercury using p-xylylene-centered dithioethers as our ligand scaffold. The rigidity of this central spacer should ensure polymer formation over mononuclear metal ion chelation. The facile synthesis of these thioether ligands has enabled this broader survey of ligand types by substituting different groups at sulfur. By changing the size of the ligand end group and the halogen counterion in the polymer, we observe structures ranging from one-dimensional (1D) polymers without any interchain close contacts to three-dimensional (3D) networks containing halide-bridged metal-ligand oligomers. The variety of structure types observed provides insight into trends in mercury coordination and may be useful in designing new mercury passivation strategies and developing design strategies for supramolecular Hg-coordination chemistry. The persistence of mercury-halide bridging has been well studied, and in future work we seek to develop supramolecular design strategies to target these specific structural motifs.

elements.content: Unless otherwise stated, all reagents and chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. NMR spectra were obtained on a Varian INOVA 300-MHz spectrometer in CDCl3 at 25 °C and referenced to TMS unless otherwise noted. IR spectra were taken on a Nicolet Magna-IR 560 FTIR spectrometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Experimental

Unless otherwise stated, all reagents and chemicals were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. NMR spectra were obtained on a Varian INOVA 300-MHz spectrometer in CDCl3 at 25 °C and referenced to TMS unless otherwise noted. IR spectra were taken on a Nicolet Magna-IR 560 FTIR spectrometer.

elements.content: Diffraction intensities for (3b·Hg2Cl4)∞, (3b·HgBr2)∞, (3a·HgI2)∞, 3b, [(3c)2(HgBr2)3]∞, and (3c·HgCl2)∞ were collected at 173(2) K on a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer using MoKα radiation λ = 0.71073 Å. Space groups were determined based on systematic absences ((3b·Hg2Cl4)∞, (3b·HgBr2)∞, (3a·HgI2)∞, and (3c·HgCl2)∞) and intensity statistics (3b, [(3c)2(HgBr2)3]∞). Absorption corrections were applied by SADABS. Structures were solved by direct methods and Fourier techniques and refined on F2 using full matrix least-squares procedures. All non-H atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. H atoms in (3b·HgBr2)∞, (3a·HgI2)∞, 3b, [(3c)2(HgBr2)3]∞ were refined in calculated positions in a rigid group model. H atoms in (3b·Hg2Cl4)∞ were found on the residual density maps and refined with isotropic thermal parameters. One of the terminal t-Bu groups in 3b is disordered over two positions with different orientations with a ratio of 0.85:0.15. It was found that the crystal structure of (3c·HgCl2)∞ in non-centrosymmetrical space group C2 consists of two structures having the same Hg2(μ-Cl)2-framework, but with two different orientations for the sulfur atoms, Ph groups and terminal Cl atoms related by a mirror plane. The Flack parameter for the structure, refined in non-centrosymmetric space group C2, was close to 0.5. Therefore, the structure of (3c·HgCl2)∞ was solved and refined in the centrosymmetric space group C2/m with the sulfur atoms, phenyl groups, and the terminal Cl atoms disordered over two positions (in a 1:1 ratio) related by a mirror plane. Hydrogen atoms were not taken into consideration in the refinement of (3c·HgCl2)∞. Thus, the X-ray structure shows that (3c·HgCl2)∞ crystallizes in space group C2 but consists of two types of infinite chains having slightly different orientations of the bridging groups. As a result, the “pseudo-symmetry” of the crystals was modeled in space group C2/m. In addition to the 3D framework formed by the main molecules, the crystal structure of (3c·HgCl2)∞ has methanol solvent molecules which are highly disordered. These methanol molecules were treated by SQUEEZE. Correction of the X-ray data by SQUEEZE (135 electron/cell) was close to the required value (144 electron/cell) for eight solvent molecules in the full unit cell. All calculations were performed by the Bruker SHELXTL (v. 6.10) package.
elements.clean_text:

Diffraction intensities for (3b⋅Hg2Cl4)∞, (3b⋅HgBr2)∞, (3a⋅HgI2)∞, 3b, [(3c)2(HgBr2)3]∞, and (3c⋅HgCl2)∞ were collected at 173(2) K on a Bruker Apex CCD diffractometer using MoKα radiation λ = 0.71073 Å. Space groups were determined based on systematic absences ((3b⋅Hg2Cl4)∞, (3b⋅HgBr2)∞, (3a⋅HgI2)∞, and (3c⋅HgCl2)∞) and intensity statistics (3b, [(3c)2(HgBr2)3]∞). Absorption corrections were applied by SADABS. Structures were solved by direct methods and Fourier techniques and refined on F2 using full matrix least-squares procedures. All non-H atoms were refined with anisotropic thermal parameters. H atoms in (3b⋅HgBr2)∞, (3a⋅HgI2)∞, 3b, [(3c)2(HgBr2)3]∞ were refined in calculated positions in a rigid group model. H atoms in (3b⋅Hg2Cl4)∞ were found on the residual density maps and refined with isotropic thermal parameters. One of the terminal t-Bu groups in 3b is disordered over two positions with different orientations with a ratio of 0.85:0.15. It was found that the crystal structure of (3c⋅HgCl2)∞ in non-centrosymmetrical space group C2 consists of two structures having the same Hg2(μ-Cl)2-framework, but with two different orientations for the sulfur atoms, Ph groups and terminal Cl atoms related by a mirror plane. The Flack parameter for the structure, refined in non-centrosymmetric space group C2, was close to 0.5. Therefore, the structure of (3c⋅HgCl2)∞ was solved and refined in the centrosymmetric space group C2/m with the sulfur atoms, phenyl groups, and the terminal Cl atoms disordered over two positions (in a 1:1 ratio) related by a mirror plane. Hydrogen atoms were not taken into consideration in the refinement of (3c⋅HgCl2)∞. Thus, the X-ray structure shows that (3c⋅HgCl2)∞ crystallizes in space group C2 but consists of two types of infinite chains having slightly different orientations of the bridging groups. As a result, the "pseudo-symmetry" of the crystals was modeled in space group C2/m. In addition to the 3D framework formed by the main molecules, the crystal structure of (3c⋅HgCl2)∞ has methanol solvent molecules which are highly disordered. These methanol molecules were treated by SQUEEZE. Correction of the X-ray data by SQUEEZE (135 electron/cell) was close to the required value (144 electron/cell) for eight solvent molecules in the full unit cell. All calculations were performed by the Bruker SHELXTL (v. 6.10) package.

elements.clean_text: 1  Synthesis of p-Xylylene Dithioethers and Their Corresponding Polymers (i) (3b and 3c) NaSR, acetone; (ii) (3a) MeI, K2CO3, DMF

elements.content: To a degassed solution of 0.30 g (1.8 mmol) of dithiol 2 in DMF (10 mL) was added 0.24 mL (3.9 mmol) of iodomethane, and the solution was further purged with N2 another 5 min. K2CO3 (0.50 g, 3.6 mmol) was added and the reaction mixture was stirred for 16 h at room temperature. The reaction was quenched with 50 mL of water and cooled at 4 °C overnight. The resulting suspension was filtered and washed with water. The crude product was filtered through a plug of silica and eluted with CHCl3/hexane (1:4) to give a clear oil, which solidified upon cooling in the refrigerator (yield: 0.177 g, 51%). 1H NMR (CDCl3): 7.25 (4H, s), 3.65 (4H, s), 1.99 (6H, s). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 77 MHz): 136.9, 128.9, 38.0, 14.9; IR (KBr, cm–1): 3046­(w), 3018­(w), 2967­(m), 2906­(s), 2845­(w), 2820­(w), 1509­(m), 1411­(s), 1243­(m), 1101­(s), 980­(s), 957­(s), 849­(s), 769­(s), 721­(s), 680­(s), 526­(s).

Synthesis of 3a 

To a degassed solution of 0.30 g (1.8 mmol) of dithiol 2  in DMF (10 mL) was added 0.24 mL (3.9 mmol) of iodomethane, and the solution was further purged with N2 another 5 min. K2CO3 (0.50 g, 3.6 mmol) was added and the reaction mixture was stirred for 16 h at room temperature. The reaction was quenched with 50 mL of water and cooled at 4 °C overnight. The resulting suspension was filtered and washed with water. The crude product was filtered through a plug of silica and eluted with CHCl3/hexane (1:4) to give a clear oil, which solidified upon cooling in the refrigerator (yield: 0.177 g, 51%). 1H NMR (CDCl3): 7.25 (4H, s), 3.65 (4H, s), 1.99 (6H, s). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 77 MHz): 136.9, 128.9, 38.0, 14.9; IR (KBr, cm-1): 3046(w), 3018(w), 2967(m), 2906(s), 2845(w), 2820(w), 1509(m), 1411(s), 1243(m), 1101(s), 980(s), 957(s), 849(s), 769(s), 721(s), 680(s), 526(s).

elements.content: To a stirring solution of 1.0 g (5.7 mmol) p-xylylene dichloride 1 in acetone (75 mL) was added 1.35 g (12.0 mmol) of sodium 2-methylpropylthiolate. The reaction was stirred 16 h at room temperature and then filtered and evaporated to yield a white solid. The crude product was filtered through a plug of silica, eluted with ethyl acetate/hexane (1:19). The solvent was removed under reduced pressure to give a white crystalline solid (yield: 1.36 g, 84%). 1H NMR (CDCl3): 7.25 (4H, s), 3.72 (4H, s), 1.33 (18H, s). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 77 MHz): 137.0, 129.0, 42.7, 33.0, 30.9; IR (KBr, cm-1): 3049­(w), 3023­(w), 2955–2857­(s), 1512­(m), 1456­(m), 1417­(m), 1361­(s), 1200­(m), 1159­(s), 1019­(w), 847­(m), 729­(s), 691­(w), 521­(s).

Synthesis of 3b. 

To a stirring solution of 1.0 g (5.7 mmol) p-xylylene dichloride 1 in acetone (75 mL) was added 1.35 g (12.0 mmol) of sodium 2-methylpropylthiolate. The reaction was stirred 16 h at room temperature and then filtered and evaporated to yield a white solid. The crude product was filtered through a plug of silica, eluted with ethyl acetate/hexane (1:19). The solvent was removed under reduced pressure to give a white crystalline solid (yield: 1.36 g, 84%). 1H NMR (CDCl3): 7.25 (4H, s), 3.72 (4H, s), 1.33 (18H, s). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 77 MHz): 137.0, 129.0, 42.7, 33.0, 30.9; IR (KBr, cm-1): 3049(w), 3023(w), 2955-2857(s), 1512(m), 1456(m), 1417(m), 1361(s), 1200(m), 1159(s), 1019(w), 847(m), 729(s), 691(w), 521(s).

elements.content: To a degassed suspension of 1.29 g (7.37 mmol) of p-xylylene dichloride 1 and 3.00 g (21.7 mmol) of K2CO3 in acetone (50 mL) was added a degassed solution of 1.82 mL (15.5 mmol) of benzyl mercaptan in acetone (10 mL) via a cannula. The reaction was then refluxed 3 days. The reaction was cooled and the solvent was removed under reduced pressure. The crude product was filtered through a plug of silica eluted with CHCl3 to remove salts and impurities. The product was dried under high vacuum for 3 h give a white crystalline solid (yield: 2.4 g, 92%). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 300 MHz): 7.23–7.30 (14H, m), 3.61 (4H, s), 3.59 (4H, s). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 77 MHz): 138.0, 136.8, 129.0, 128.9, 128.4, 126.9, 35.6, 35.2; IR (KBr, cm-1): 3059­(s), 3026­(w), 2957­(w), 2922­(w), 1598­(m), 1507­(m), 1492­(s), 1450­(s), 1413­(s), 1235­(m), 1198­(m), 1097­(m), 1068­(s), 1025­(s), 841­(s), 774­(s), 697­(vs), 670­(m), 561­(s), 522­(s).

To a degassed suspension of 1.29 g (7.37 mmol) of p-xylylene dichloride 1 and 3.00 g (21.7 mmol) of K2CO3 in acetone (50 mL) was added a degassed solution of 1.82 mL (15.5 mmol) of benzyl mercaptan in acetone (10 mL) via a cannula. elements.content: Coordination polymers were formed by layering a methanolic solution of a mercury salt over a methylene chloride solution of the respective ligand. The solutions were left open to air and crystals grew, in most cases in less than 24 h. X-ray quality crystals were grown for (3a·HgI2)∞, 3b, (3b·Hg2Cl4)∞, (3b·HgBr2)∞, (3c·HgCl2)∞, [(3c)2(HgBr2)3]∞. In all cases, the ratio of mercury to ligand in the crystallization was constant at 1:1. Mercury ligand complexes were not persistent in solution and were characterized by IR (KBr pellets) and single crystal X-ray diffraction.
elements.clean_text:
General Synthesis of Mercury Coordination Polymers

Coordination polymers were formed by layering a methanolic solution of a mercury salt over a methylene chloride solution of the respective ligand. The solutions were left open to air and crystals grew, in most cases in less than 24 h. X-ray quality crystals were grown for (3a⋅HgI2)∞, 3b, (3b⋅Hg2Cl4)∞, (3b⋅HgBr2)∞, (3c⋅HgCl2)∞, [(3c)2(HgBr2)3]∞. In all cases, the ratio of mercury to ligand in the crystallization was constant at 1:1. Mercury ligand complexes were not persistent in solution and were characterized by IR (KBr pellets) and single crystal X-ray diffraction.

elements.content: HgI2 was the only mercury halide which formed high quality crystals for X-ray analysis when combined with ligand 3a. HgCl2 and HgBr2 also precipitated microcrystalline material but large, well-separated crystals remain elusive. The small methyl substituents of this dithioether ligand provide enough steric space around the mercury atom to accommodate the large iodine atoms. The resulting 1D coordination polymer forms stacked sheets (Figure ). In one dimension, the coordination polymers are well-spaced with the closest contact (3.132 Å) between iodine and a neighboring phenyl ring. The polymers show complementary orientation of the halogens along the stacks and alternating halogen orientations along the polymer backbones resulting in favorable S···I interactions. In the unit cell there are two types of crystallographically distinct mercury atoms with slightly different Hg–I (2.7203(4) and 2.7281(4) Å) and Hg–S (2.6431(13) and 2.6619(13) Å) bond lengths. These bond lengths differ greatly from the limited examples of diiododithioether mercury complexes found in the CSD, which have an average Hg–I bond distance of 2.63 ± 0.03 Å and Hg–S bond length of 2.7 ± 0.1 Å. This shorter Hg–S bond can be rationalized by the relatively minimal steric constraints around mercury and additional intermolecular interactions, such as S···I and π-stacking, leading to tighter packing within the stacks of polymers. The coordination geometry around the mercury atoms, as a result of these factors, is very distorted tetrahedral. The close contact (3.207 Ǻ) between edge carbons of stacked phenyl rings may also be stabilizing the stacking of the 1D polymers. This slipped form of stacking may simply be a result of the steric requirements of stacking the diiodide-containing polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Results

Structure of (3a⋅HgI2)∞ 

HgI2 was the only mercury halide which formed high quality crystals for X-ray analysis when combined with ligand 3a. HgCl2 and HgBr2 also precipitated microcrystalline material but large, well-separated crystals remain elusive. The small methyl substituents of this dithioether ligand provide enough steric space around the mercury atom to accommodate the large iodine atoms. The resulting 1D coordination polymer forms stacked sheets (Figure ). In one dimension, the coordination polymers are well-spaced with the closest contact (3.132 Å) between iodine and a neighboring phenyl ring. The polymers show complementary orientation of the halogens along the stacks and alternating halogen orientations along the polymer backbones resulting in favorable S⋅⋅⋅I interactions. In the unit cell there are two types of crystallographically distinct mercury atoms with slightly different Hg-I (2.7203(4) and 2.7281(4) Å) and Hg-S (2.6431(13) and 2.6619(13) Å) bond lengths. These bond lengths differ greatly from the limited examples of diiododithioether mercury complexes found in the CSD, which have an average Hg-I bond distance of 2.63 ± 0.03 Å and Hg-S bond length of 2.7 ± 0.1 Å. This shorter Hg-S bond can be rationalized by the relatively minimal steric constraints around mercury and additional intermolecular interactions, such as S⋅⋅⋅I and π-stacking, leading to tighter packing within the stacks of polymers. The coordination geometry around the mercury atoms, as a result of these factors, is very distorted tetrahedral. The close contact (3.207 Ǻ) between edge carbons of stacked phenyl rings may also be stabilizing the stacking of the 1D polymers. This slipped form of stacking may simply be a result of the steric requirements of stacking the diiodide-containing polymers.

Attempts were made to form thioether complexes with Hg­(CN)2 using all three ligands 3a–c presented above. Unfortunately, no mercury containing species were isolated from mixtures with any of these ligands. However, attempts to form coordination complexes with Hg­(CN)2 and ligand 3b resulted in the isolation of X-ray quality crystals of the 3b alone.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of 3b 

Attempts were made to form thioether complexes with Hg(CN)2 using all three ligands 3a-c presented above. Unfortunately, no mercury containing species were isolated from mixtures with any of these ligands. However, attempts to form coordination complexes with Hg(CN)2 and ligand 3b resulted in the isolation of X-ray quality crystals of the 3b alone.

elements.content: The unit cell contains two molecules of the ligand with disorder in one t-butyl group of one of the molecules. The molecules are arranged in sheets of offset stacks where the t-butyl groups of one molecule are located directly above the phenyl ring of the neighbor below. Surprisingly, there are no π-stacking or S···S interactions seen throughout the crystal as have been observed for numerous related molecules.
elements.clean_text: The unit cell contains two molecules of the ligand with disorder in one t-butyl group of one of the molecules. The molecules are arranged in sheets of offset stacks where the t-butyl groups of one molecule are located directly above the phenyl ring of the neighbor below. Surprisingly, there are no π-stacking or S⋅⋅⋅S interactions seen throughout the crystal as have been observed for numerous related molecules.

elements.content: In coordination polymers containing HgCl2 subunits, retention of bridging chlorides is common. The two mercury ions in the repeated unit are connected through a parallelogram of dative bonds constructed of bridging chlorides. The Hg–Cl bonds linking the two mercury atoms are not the same length, 2.5959(9) Ǻ and 2.6465(8) Ǻ. The tetrahedral geometry at mercury is distorted to an angle between adjacent ligand pairs of 82.61° (angle between Cl(1)–Hg–Cl­(1A) and S–Hg–Cl(2) planes). As expected, the nonbridging chloride forms the shortest bond to mercury at 2.3767(8) Ǻ. The Hg–S bond length in this polymer is 2.4704(8) Å. These bond lengths are consistent with the average bond lengths found for Hg2Cl4(thioether)2 fragments found in the CSD. A short contact of 2.866 Å exists between one hydrogen connected to C(1) and a bridging chloride Cl(1). This interaction is consistent with a nonclassical C–H···Cl-M hydrogen bond and helps to dictate the packing in this coordination polymer.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of (3b⋅Hg2Cl4)∞ 

In coordination polymers containing HgCl2 subunits, retention of bridging chlorides is common. The two mercury ions in the repeated unit are connected through a parallelogram of dative bonds constructed of bridging chlorides. The Hg-Cl bonds linking the two mercury atoms are not the same length, 2.5959(9) Ǻ and 2.6465(8) Ǻ. The tetrahedral geometry at mercury is distorted to an angle between adjacent ligand pairs of 82.61° (angle between Cl(1)-Hg-Cl(1A) and S-Hg-Cl(2) planes). As expected, the nonbridging chloride forms the shortest bond to mercury at 2.3767(8) Ǻ. The Hg-S bond length in this polymer is 2.4704(8) Å. These bond lengths are consistent with the average bond lengths found for Hg2Cl4(thioether)2 fragments found in the CSD. A short contact of 2.866 Å exists between one hydrogen connected to C(1) and a bridging chloride Cl(1). This interaction is consistent with a nonclassical C-H⋅⋅⋅Cl-M hydrogen bond and helps to dictate the packing in this coordination polymer.

elements.content: Like the above-mentioned structure of 3a·HgI2, the mercury bromide fragment in 3b·HgBr2 is isolated, lacking any μ-Br bridging to adjacent Hg centers. Unlike 3a·HgI2, however, 3b·HgBr2 contains no sulfur–halogen close contacts or intermolecular π–π interactions, and the packing in this crystal seems to be controlled entirely by steric constraints. The mercury bromide fragment folds back on the phenyl portion in a compact, zigzag fashion (Figure ). The Hg–S bond lengths are all the same at 2.6598(10) Ǻ and the Hg–Br bond lengths are also equal at 2.5334(7) Ǻ. The bond length for Hg–Br is consistent with the average bond length found for HgBr2(thioether)2 fragments found in the CSD. However, the Hg–S bonds found in this structure are 0.092 Ǻ smaller than the average found for similar structures suggesting a stronger bond within this polymer. The planes described by S–Hg–S and Br–Hg–Br form an angle of 80.57° indicating even stronger distortion away from a tetrahedral geometry than that observed for 3b·Hg2Cl4. This can be rationalized by the large steric burden of the t-Bu groups surrounding mercury.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of (3b⋅HgBr2)∞ 

Like the above-mentioned structure of 3a⋅HgI2, the mercury bromide fragment in 3b⋅HgBr2 is isolated, lacking any μ-Br bridging to adjacent Hg centers. Unlike 3a⋅HgI2, however, 3b⋅HgBr2 contains no sulfur-halogen close contacts or intermolecular π-π interactions, and the packing in this crystal seems to be controlled entirely by steric constraints. The mercury bromide fragment folds back on the phenyl portion in a compact, zigzag fashion (Figure ). The Hg-S bond lengths are all the same at 2.6598(10) Ǻ and the Hg-Br bond lengths are also equal at 2.5334(7) Ǻ. The bond length for Hg-Br is consistent with the average bond length found for HgBr2(thioether)2 fragments found in the CSD. However, the Hg-S bonds found in this structure are 0.092 Ǻ smaller than the average found for similar structures suggesting a stronger bond within this polymer. The planes described by S-Hg-S and Br-Hg-Br form an angle of 80.57° indicating even stronger distortion away from a tetrahedral geometry than that observed for 3b⋅Hg2Cl4. This can be rationalized by the large steric burden of the t-Bu groups surrounding mercury.

elements.content: This molecular network differs from the other structures by containing separated (HgCl2)∞ polymers linked entirely by μ-Cl bridges. These 1D inorganic polymers are then linked by the bridging xylyl-spacer in the 3c ligands, resulting in a 2D sheet of nested 1D polymers. These sheets are further separated by the pendant benzyl groups of the ligand, extending past the coordinating sulfur. This separation between the sheets of polymers is quite large at 8.8 Å allowing for substantial void space, which is filled by disordered solvent of crystallization. The coordination geometry at mercury in these sheets is distorted trigonal bipyramidal. The bond lengths in this mercury chloride polymer are very similar to those found for (3b·Hg2Cl4)∞ with the exception of one Hg–Cl bond (2.956 Å), which forms between repeat units in the growing direction of the polymer. This long bond length suggests that this coordination polymer might best be described as repeating T-shaped HgCl2-thiol fragments connected by two bridging dative bonds on each side of the mercury centered, T-shaped fragment.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of (3c⋅HgCl2)

This molecular network differs from the other structures by containing separated (HgCl2)∞ polymers linked entirely by μ-Cl bridges. These 1D inorganic polymers are then linked by the bridging xylyl-spacer in the 3c ligands, resulting in a 2D sheet of nested 1D polymers. These sheets are further separated by the pendant benzyl groups of the ligand, extending past the coordinating sulfur. This separation between the sheets of polymers is quite large at 8.8 Å allowing for substantial void space, which is filled by disordered solvent of crystallization. The coordination geometry at mercury in these sheets is distorted trigonal bipyramidal. The bond lengths in this mercury chloride polymer are very similar to those found for (3b⋅Hg2Cl4)∞ with the exception of one Hg-Cl bond (2.956 Å), which forms between repeat units in the growing direction of the polymer. This long bond length suggests that this coordination polymer might best be described as repeating T-shaped HgCl2-thiol fragments connected by two bridging dative bonds on each side of the mercury centered, T-shaped fragment.

elements.content: The main feature of this coordination network is the oligomerization of thioether-ligated mercury bromide fragments within the larger coordination polymer matrix. These rod-like segments in the network contain two sets of three crystallographically distinct mercury atoms fused together to form a six-mercury containing ladderane-like structure (Figure a). Of these six, four mercury atoms are linked in a bridged, distorted trigonal bipyramidal array. This oligomeric fragment is capped by two mercury ions in a distorted disphenoidal complex ligated by two thioether ligands. The bulk of the structure consists of dithioether ligands cross-linking the mercury bromide clusters. Two of the dithioether ligands bridge between horizontal mercury bromide oligomers, while two other end-capping ligands bridge to two more mercury bromide oligomers resulting in a 3D network of interconnected inorganic fragments. The central portion of these linked bars is structurally similar to (3c·HgCl2)∞. The linked HgBr2-thioether fragments are no longer T-shaped as they were in the previous structure but are similarly joined by long bonds (linking Hg–Br distances range between 3.0206(5) and 3.370 Å). The bonds within this repeating fragment are comparable to those found in a structurally related mercury bromide thioether polymer containing a Hg–Br framework similar to (3b·Hg2Cl4)∞.
elements.clean_text:
Structure of [(3c)2(HgBr2)3]∞ 

The main feature of this coordination network is the oligomerization of thioether-ligated mercury bromide fragments within the larger coordination polymer matrix. These rod-like segments in the network contain two sets of three crystallographically distinct mercury atoms fused together to form a six-mercury containing ladderane-like structure (Figure a). Of these six, four mercury atoms are linked in a bridged, distorted trigonal bipyramidal array. This oligomeric fragment is capped by two mercury ions in a distorted disphenoidal complex ligated by two thioether ligands. The bulk of the structure consists of dithioether ligands cross-linking the mercury bromide clusters. Two of the dithioether ligands bridge between horizontal mercury bromide oligomers, while two other end-capping ligands bridge to two more mercury bromide oligomers resulting in a 3D network of interconnected inorganic fragments. The central portion of these linked bars is structurally similar to (3c⋅HgCl2)∞. The linked HgBr2-thioether fragments are no longer T-shaped as they were in the previous structure but are similarly joined by long bonds (linking Hg-Br distances range between 3.0206(5) and 3.370 Å). The bonds within this repeating fragment are comparable to those found in a structurally related mercury bromide thioether polymer containing a Hg-Br framework similar to (3b⋅Hg2Cl4)∞.

elements.content: The ligands chosen for this study contain very similar structural and electronic properties with respect to the donating sulfur atoms. The same para-bis-mercaptomethylbenzene core is present in all three ligands with an average distance between sulfur atoms of 7.867 Å across the structures shown here. The structural rigidity of this core spacer ensures that the two thioether donors cannot bond to the same mercury ion, inducing coordination polymer formation. These rigidly held sulfur atoms are also each bonded to two sp3-hybridized carbon atoms resulting in very similar electron donating properties at sulfur. In spite of these similarities, the variety of connectivities that result from ligation to mercury halides is quite remarkable. They range from discrete 1D polymers in the case of (3b·HgBr2)∞ to fully cross-linked 3D ensembles in the case of [(3c)2(HgBr2)3]∞. Much of the difference in structural motifs can be explained by the difference in steric environments of the ligands, but the role of the counterion should not be neglected. As a structural element in potential ligand design or crystal engineering applications, the ability of mercury halides to self-associate through secondary bonding interactions, weak dative bonding, or direct μ-halide bridging separates the ligands from otherwise potentially associative close contacts.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

The ligands chosen for this study contain very similar structural and electronic properties with respect to the donating sulfur atoms. The same para-bis-mercaptomethylbenzene core is present in all three ligands with an average distance between sulfur atoms of 7.867 Å across the structures shown here. The structural rigidity of this core spacer ensures that the two thioether donors cannot bond to the same mercury ion, inducing coordination polymer formation. These rigidly held sulfur atoms are also each bonded to two sp3-hybridized carbon atoms resulting in very similar electron donating properties at sulfur. In spite of these similarities, the variety of connectivities that result from ligation to mercury halides is quite remarkable. They range from discrete 1D polymers in the case of (3b⋅HgBr2)∞ to fully cross-linked 3D ensembles in the case of [(3c)2(HgBr2)3]∞. Much of the difference in structural motifs can be explained by the difference in steric environments of the ligands, but the role of the counterion should not be neglected. As a structural element in potential ligand design or crystal engineering applications, the ability of mercury halides to self-associate through secondary bonding interactions, weak dative bonding, or direct μ-halide bridging separates the ligands from otherwise potentially associative close contacts.

elements.content: Although a ratio of metal to ligand of 1:1 was used in each crystallization, mercuric chloride and bromide remain associated through bridging halogens in the solid state in the cases of (3b·Hg2Cl4)∞, [(3c)2(HgBr2)3]∞, and (3c·HgCl2)∞. The number of bridging halogen interactions between mercury and chloride is most likely a consequence of the steric bulk surrounding the mercury atom. Oligomers and coordination polymers have also been observed when mixed mercury thiolate halogen complexes have been prepared. When HgCl2 or HgBr2 was added to a solution of 3a, microcrystalline solids did result but we were unable to grow crystals of sufficient size and quality for X-ray analysis. Larger and less stable aggregates of HgX2 have been observed in mercury chloride thioether complex formation, and this may account for the instability of the mercury–3a complexes with more tightly bound halogens.

The number of bridging halogen interactions between mercury and chloride is most likely a consequence of the steric bulk surrounding the mercury atom. Oligomers and coordination polymers have also been observed when mixed mercury thiolate halogen complexes have been prepared. When HgCl2 or HgBr2 was added to a solution of 3a, microcrystalline solids did result but we were unable to grow crystals of sufficient size and quality for X-ray analysis. Larger and less stable aggregates of HgX2 have been observed in mercury chloride thioether complex formation, and this may account for the instability of the mercury-3a complexes with more tightly bound halogens.

elements.content: No crystals were obtained from attempts to treat HgI2 with ligands 3b or 3c. This can be readily explained by the steric demand at sulfur in these two ligands. Models constructed with these ligand–anion combinations show obvious steric disruptions corroborating this supposition.
elements.clean_text: No crystals were obtained from attempts to treat HgI2 with ligands 3b or 3c. This can be readily explained by the steric demand at sulfur in these two ligands. Models constructed with these ligand-anion combinations show obvious steric disruptions corroborating this supposition.

elements.content: We have shown that by varying the steric profile of rigid dithioether ligands, the nature of the mercury coordination polymers can be tuned. The size and nature of the counterion can also dictate the nature of a mercury thioether coordination network including whether or not well-defined crystals readily form. Within these polymers, we propose that the most important factors dictating overall structure in this polymer type are the strength of the mercury halide dative bond, the steric constraints surrounding mercury, and the complementary packing of potential metal ligand arrays. Applying these factors to ligand design, we hope to overcome the tendency of mercury to form bridged networks in order to form discrete, supramolecular self-assembled structures, something that, with a few notable exceptions, has been relatively unexplored. Furthermore, given the speciation of Hg­(II) in solutions with high halide concentration, understanding the coordination chemistry of the HgX2 fragments is vitally important to problems in environmental chemistry of mercury coordination complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have shown that by varying the steric profile of rigid dithioether ligands, the nature of the mercury coordination polymers can be tuned. The size and nature of the counterion can also dictate the nature of a mercury thioether coordination network including whether or not well-defined crystals readily form. Within these polymers, we propose that the most important factors dictating overall structure in this polymer type are the strength of the mercury halide dative bond, the steric constraints surrounding mercury, and the complementary packing of potential metal ligand arrays. Applying these factors to ligand design, we hope to overcome the tendency of mercury to form bridged networks in order to form discrete, supramolecular self-assembled structures, something that, with a few notable exceptions, has been relatively unexplored. Furthermore, given the speciation of Hg(II) in solutions with high halide concentration, understanding the coordination chemistry of the HgX2 fragments is vitally important to problems in environmental chemistry of mercury coordination complexes.

cln_elements.content:
To a degassed solution of 0.30 g (1.8 mmol) of dithiol 2 in DMF (10 mL) was added 0.24 mL (3.9 mmol) of iodomethane, and the solution was further purged with N2 another 5 min. K2CO3 (0.50 g, 3.6 mmol) was added and the reaction mixture was stirred for 16 h at room temperature. The reaction was quenched with 50 mL of water and cooled at 4 °C overnight. The resulting suspension was filtered and washed with water. The crude product was filtered through a plug of silica and eluted with CHCl3/hexane (1:4) to give a clear oil, which solidified upon cooling in the refrigerator (yield: 0.177 g, 51%). 1H NMR (CDCl3): 7.25 (4H, s), 3.65 (4H, s), 1.99 (6H, s). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 77 MHz): 136.9, 128.9, 38.0, 14.9; IR (KBr, cm–1): 3046­(w), 3018­(w), 2967­(m), 2906­(s), 2845­(w), 2820­(w), 1509­(m), 1411­(s), 1243­(m), 1101­(s), 980­(s), 957­(s), 849­(s), 769­(s), 721­(s), 680­(s), 526­(s).

Synthesis of <bold>3b</bold>.

To a stirring solution of 1.0 g (5.7 mmol) p-xylylene dichloride 1 in acetone (75 mL) was added 1.35 g (12.0 mmol) of sodium 2-methylpropylthiolate. The reaction was stirred 16 h at room temperature and then filtered and evaporated to yield a white solid. The crude product was filtered through a plug of silica, eluted with ethyl acetate/hexane (1:19). The solvent was removed under reduced pressure to give a white crystalline solid (yield: 1.36 g, 84%). 1H NMR (CDCl3): 7.25 (4H, s), 3.72 (4H, s), 1.33 (18H, s). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 77 MHz): 137.0, 129.0, 42.7, 33.0, 30.9; IR (KBr, cm-1): 3049­(w), 3023­(w), 2955–2857­(s), 1512­(m), 1456­(m), 1417­(m), 1361­(s), 1200­(m), 1159­(s), 1019­(w), 847­(m), 729­(s), 691­(w), 521­(s).

Synthesis of <bold>3c</bold>.

To a degassed suspension of 1.29 g (7.37 mmol) of p-xylylene dichloride 1 and 3.00 g (21.7 mmol) of K2CO3 in acetone (50 mL) was added a degassed solution of 1.82 mL (15.5 mmol) of benzyl mercaptan in acetone (10 mL) via a cannula. The reaction was then refluxed 3 days. The reaction was cooled and the solvent was removed under reduced pressure. The crude product was filtered through a plug of silica eluted with CHCl3 to remove salts and impurities. The product was dried under high vacuum for 3 h give a white crystalline solid (yield: 2.4 g, 92%). 1H NMR (CDCl3, 300 MHz): 7.23–7.30 (14H, m), 3.61 (4H, s), 3.59 (4H, s). 13C NMR (CDCl3, 77 MHz): 138.0, 136.8, 129.0, 128.9, 128.4, 126.9, 35.6, 35.2; IR (KBr, cm-1): 3059­(s), 3026­(w), 2957­(w), 2922­(w), 1598­(m), 1507­(m), 1492­(s), 1450­(s), 1413­(s), 1235­(m), 1198­(m), 1097­(m), 1068­(s), 1025­(s), 841­(s), 774­(s), 697­(vs), 670­(m), 561­(s), 522­(s).

(3a·HgI2)∞: IR (KBr, cm–1): 3025­(w), 2909­(w), 1512­(m), 1416­(vs), 1313­(w), 1247­(w), 1150­(w), 1106­(m), 1018­(w), 981­(m), 962­(s), 852­(s), 769­(m), 662­(s), 716­(w), 521­(m) white crystalline solid (33.5 mg, 68%).
